or;6ce was bleeding aifesh. I shrUInk abash- cd at the prepOsterous charge I had made, and after endeavOring to appease his injured feelings, withdrew and left him to the care Of the physician. His eyes followed me, and felt relieved when I had escaped from their glare.

 I retired to my birth, and endeavOred to sleep, but my mind had become so feverish by the dreadful occurrences of the night, that tossed about for several hours in painful state of restlessness. At length fell into slurnber, but it was slumber more dreadful than my waking contemplations for the ghastly face of the seaman was seen where ever turned my eyes. It assumed various expressions, and was blended in my imagina- ton with the figure of the murdered Camp bell, producing succession of scenes and shapes that would have driven the waking inn agination to frenzy. arose early and hasten ed on deck, happy to escape to scene of life and hustle, from the solitary horrors of the night. The storm still continued, and ap- pearances indicated that it would do so for some days.

 Mrs. Campbell watched by the beside of her husband during the night, in a state of agony that can be more readily conceived than described; for the surgeon on examining the wound, pronounced a speedy death inev- itable. When the earthly ties which bind the pure to the innocent are violently 'vered, the pang sustained by the survivoris too frequent ly almost insupportable, although the bright promise of meeting hereafter may cast ray of comfort around the heart of the mourner {; what then must the guilty feel, who are bound by ties that cannot exist in heaven, and which, when broken here, leave the torn heart with out hope remaining! The mournful visage ofMrs. Campbell, as she clasped the hand of the dying man, was painful to behold, for even the most careless observer could discov- CT utter hopelessness written there.

 The surgeon on interrogating Campbelre- specting the manner in which the wound was inflicted, was led to believe that the unhappy and mysterious man had fallen the victim of his own hand, and the deep rooted melancho ly that had obtained possession of his mind and actions, rendered it highly probable that this supposition was correct. When first car ried below, after his wound had been staunch- ed, he turned to his wife and said in tone scarcely audible, "behold my prediction yer flied; you treated lightly my superstitlous feelings; but had prescience that should never tread on earth again.

 (Concluded in our nert.)

On Friday oflast week, fatal accident occurred in the town of Southeast. which has brought affliction into the bosom of respectable family.-Hart Crosby, son of MT. Thomas Crosby, who it appears had TOT some time been practising with view .. S escoming Circus Rider, xc. on the ISay ,Sy aoove mentioned, in attempting to 'nrow a somerset, struck on his head with

 such violence that it disloeated the mock joints. He lived about 12 hours, and then expired. This is the second accident of this nature' which has proved fatal, in that neighbourhood, within the last six months From these we may hope caution mav be derived, that will deter young men from engaging in pursuit, not only SO dangerous to life, but demoraliaing to com munitv.

Dr. MELLEN, Sir-the cause of humanity demands of me to give the following state ment: My wife had for six years been in decline and pronounced by her Physicians to be in consumptive state, and was attended by severe pain in her side, with Cough E difficulty of breathing. She was reduced so low as to be unable to get from her bed to the fire without aid. All hopes of her recovery had long been given up. In this situation, was prevailed upon, as a last possible resort, yet without any hopes of success, to make use of" Anderson's Cough Drops" She com menced the use of them in February last and after using two bottles, to the astonlshment of all, in the month of May following the health of my wife was entirely restored, and since which, her health and strength were perhaps never better. Feeling deep interest that the public in general may resort 10 the same remedy, when their friends and relatives are apparently, or evidently on the brink of the grave, to rescue them from from the same You are at liberty to publish the above.

 am respectfully, S1c.

 Rhinebeck, Duchess co. N. Y.) Nor. 8. 1926"

 This is to certify that the subscriber. was brought very low by splitting blood, attended with cough and catarril, and that nothing afforded me real relief until commenced ta- king Anderson's Cough Drops, the use of which were the means in the hand of God of restoring me again to comfortable state Of health.

 And do further certify that the wife of Mir. Nathan Huntington, living in the same place was afflicted with very bad cough for num- ber of years, and that in 1923 she was redu- ced so low that it was thought she must soon be in her grave, as she was scarcely able to walk from her bed to the fire, when she com menced taking Andersen's Cough Drops, the use of which, in short time so far restored her, that she was soon able to do good days work. can cheerfully recommend this med icine to the public.

 PHILO HUDSON, Pastor

 of the Church in Ashford, (Conn.l

 Ashford, Sept. 25, 1924.

 THE Administrator represents the Estate l insolvent, and prays the appointment of Commissioners thereon

 Ordered, That Commissioners to receive and examine the claims of the creditors of said Estate be appointed at the Probate Office in New Milford, on the 9th day of April 1927, at 10 o'clock, forenoon: of which all persons in interest will take notice and appear if they see cause and be heard thereon.

DISTRICT OF NEW MILFORD, ss. Probate Court, March IA, 1927.

MELANCHOLH SftlF w hECk.

 Extract of aletter from Capt. James H. Dill, late master of brig Potomac, of Bos- ton,

 "ST. CRUZ. Teneriffe, Nov. 20, 1926.

 "Sir: am sorry to have to announce to you the unfortunate loss of the Potomac. When we had performed .our quarantine, and discharged our cargo that we had to Grand Canary, we came directly to this place, and were waiting hero to obtain li- cence from the government to take passen- gers, for within few months an order has

 been sent out here, from the King, preven- ting aN foreign vessels from taking natives of these Islands away consequently we kept the vessel here to wait the result of an interview with the government, to go on with the expedition, and finally, few days previous to the loss of the vessel, we succeeded, and had taken in large quan- tity of store, &c. for the passengers and, the day before we were ready to sail for Lanzarretto, there came on one of the most tremendous hurricanes that the old est inhabitants remember to have witness ed in these islands. Notwithstanding it came on very suddenly, and right on shore, I had got off cabin cable.and anchor, from the shore, before the communication to the vessel became impracticable--b the storm ragged with incseasing fury, every vessel parted, and went on to the beach, one af- ter another, the wind hauled every fifteen | minutes, so that no vessel could ride strain on more than one cable, till at length my small bower parted, and the chain was let go, and scope vered out-the sea was very bad, the boats all washed away, the vessel was unable to bear so hard labour, and leaked very badly still every thing was done to keep her free, and save her, but all in vain-at half past 9, the best bower parted, and the chain and anchor would not bring her up, and she was dash ed against the rocks, and in five minutes nothing was to be seen of the Potomac but some small pieces afoat in the surf; and with her, my mate and cook shared the same fate the rest, some made their es- cape by throwing themselves from the yards and rigging on to the rocks, and some were thrown up by the sea on to the rocks, with broken arms and legs and have scarcely recovered yet sufficiently to write you description of the shocking scene. The general destruction, in all the island. has not left vessel that we can procure.''

 The Potomac was to take her passen- gers at Lanzaretto, and proceed to Monte Video.
MELANCHOLY SHIPWRECK.

Thousands have experienced the happy ef- tects of this Healing Balsae, and many of the highest responsibility have voluntarily given certificates, some of which will accompany each bottle, that will satisfy every uuprciudi- ced mind that the most extraordinary and un- expected cures have been performed by the use of this medicine in cases of long standing, m which other medicine. had produced no favourable effects, and where the most skill Iul Physicians had given them up as hopeless. u IS not pretended that they are an infallible cure inaall cases, but of such as are incurable, there are but few but what will be greatly re- lleved by the use of them. Situated in VERGENNES, in the State of Vermont, upon the falls of Otter Creek. The local situation of this Furnace is as good, if not better, than any in the State of Vermont, being in the village of Vergennes, and with in one hundred rods of water carriage to any part of the Lake, or New-York, by way of the Northern Canal. The best of OAR for making Stove Plates or Hollow Ware, may be had within few miles, or may be brought from the shores of Lake Champlan, by wa ter. Coal in great abundance may be had on ashort notice. The Furnace will be sold ve- ry low. Only part of the purchase money will be wanted this spring, the remainder in yearly payments: For further particulars inquire of MOSES COUPON,

 40 of Fair-Haven, Rutland Go. Vt.
FOR SALE, A Bt, ASST FURNACE

The dress of the Spanish lady is remarka- ply elegant, generally adorns very perfect shape. Black is the universal color, and the robe is most tastefully worked and vandyk- ed. A montilla or veil of black silk or lace and sometimes white lace, is thrown over the head, and leaving the face uncovered, falls gracefully over the head and shoulders and is confined at the waist by the arms of the wearer They are both expensive and particular in dressing their feet with neat ness, and their little shoes fit closely. The large black eye, the dark expressive glance, the soft blood-tinged olive of the glowing complexion, make tho unwilling English man confess the majesty of Spanish beauty and he feels that tho the soft blue eye, and delicate loveliness of his own countrywo- men awake amore tender feeling of interest he would deny or dispute, in vain, the com manding superiority of those dark-eyed and fair-formed damsels.
Spanish Ladies.

Continued. ~

 We had experienced for several days m sue cession nearly a dead calm. Campbell had heretofore admired and enjoyed this state of the elements, for what is better calculated to raise the contemplative mind from earthly matters than to behold in an autumn evening a cloudless sky reflected on the glassy surface of the slumbering ocean? But now the dead calm was torture to his restless spirit. He prayed for motion, and his impatlence was betrayed in every action. His eyes were wild and wandering, and his movements abrupt and hurried. He inquired of the oldest sea man from which quarter of the compass might. be expected the approach of the next tenn pest. and to that quarter were his eyes con stantly directed, where every ascending cloud appeared to bring a fresh hope to his desOlate heart.

 At length tie long looked for storm arose in all its grandeur. Volumes of dense clouds regularly and gradually ascended like forlni- dabIe armies preparing for battle. The winds that had been pent up, now burst forth, and the roaring waters heaved with a convulsive motion. The spell was broke that had har- monized creation, and discord now prevailed The appearance of Campbell became visibiy changed. His countenance was animated ;- there was a smile of terrible, but undefned meaning upon his lips; his eyes glanced wild ly from the sea te the heavens, and he tra- versed the deck with a rapidity of step that excited the wonder of all who beheld him. Our vessel was soon prepared to encounter the worst but as the wind blew steadily from one quarter we felt no apprehensions for eur safety.-The sky was completely overcast, and the rain descended in torrents. Campbell still remained upon deck, after all the passen- gers and crew, excepting those upon watch, had retired to rest. No persuasion could in- duce him to go below, and to the entreaties ofhis wife and the captain, he replied: " It is the only joyful hour l have experienced since came on board; Ibeseechs you not to interruptit."

 They left him, and he seated himselfin the most retired part of the ship, to brood upon his feelings had retired to my birth, but found it impossible to close my eyes, for the raging waters made such an awful coil as they dashed against the sides of the ship, and gave rise to reflections that would have kept me awake even had my mind been fortified with the philosophy of the little Captain. After tossing in my bed for about two hours, until the fever of my mind was communicated to my body, imagined hearda piercing shriek proceeding from the deck. It was immediate ly followed by groan. leaped from my bed and rushed to the gangway. l met the captain at the foot of the stairs, who had been awakened by the same noise. On seeing me, he exclaimed Mon dieu le melancaolique gentlehomme !" and ascended as rapidly as his ,diminutive legs would carry him. I follow ed him, and we hurried towards the place where we had left Campbell the preceding evening. m

 Lights were speedily brought, and lying on the deck we beheld Campbell, welterng in his blood. l raised him-the wound was in his bosom, and bleeding proftlsely.- "Good God '' exclaimed, "who has done 1his 2"

 "The Tempest Fiend," he answered. "We have had a long and fearful struggle ;- but thank God, it is over. Iproved unequal to the combat, and he has marked me for the caverns ofthe deep." He laughed hysterical- ly, and big drops of precipitation burst from his pale forehead. l called for assistance to carry him below.

 "NO, no," he cried, "let me die here. I shall be called fer before to-morrows sun ri- ses, for the spirits ofthe water are preparing my abode in their coral caves. Let me rest here until they come for me-"

 The captain demanded of the sailors who were on watch, an explanation of this melan- choly and mysterious occurrence. They sta kCN uAotS uulHIS IIC IntcTSdlS OI tue storm, they had heard voices, but conceived them to be nothing more than the rawlings of c Campbell One man, however, protested that immedi- ately after the shriek, vivid flash of lightning afforded him amomentary and indistinct view of figure gliding down the gangway of the forecastle. Suspicion Immediately fell on the shipwrecked stranger, for adyersty is too frequently considered by the prosperous, su- periOr to no action, however atrocious. The physician vouched for the innocence of his patient, declaring it physically impossible that he could stir from his hammock. He pro- nounced him in fair way to recover, but as yet incapable of moving. "And then what motiye," said he, could possibly exist in the bosom of man, himself apparently on the verge of eternity. sufficient to excite exhaust ed nature to the performance of the act of fend 2"

 Campbell was carried below, and after his wound was staunched, was left alone with his wife, the presence of any other person being painful to him. We then entered the place where the sick sailor lay, and on beholding him readily admitted that we did him injustice by ' the suspicion we had entertained. But as we were about to leave him, l imagined esped a speck of blood on the covering of the he'd. One of his hands hung over the side of the hammock; the light fell upon it. and betray- ed that 1t also was stained with blood Con victiOn flashed on the minds of all ,,ros.x4

A traveller setting out upon long journey was assailed by CUTS, mastifs, ,and lfgrowu puppies, which came out of their kennels to bark at him as he passed along. He often dismounted from the horse to drive them back with stones and sticks, into their hiding places. This operation was repeated every day, and some times as often as twenty times day. The consequence was, that the travellers time was consumed in chastis- ing these dogs and puppies. At last he was overtaken by neighbor, who was going the some road ,but had set out long time after him. The latter traveller was very much surprized to find the other no further on his journey, and on hearing the reason, 'Alas" ssid he, lis it possible that you have; lost your time, and wasted your strength in this useless way? These same ani- malls have beset me all along the road, ,bu, I have saved my time and my labor, in taking no notice of their barkings; while you have lost yours in resenting insults VI 'ch did you no harm, and in chastising dogs & puppies whose manners you can never mend. .''-V;2ps. .>
AZLegOric0L.

ESTATES OF DAVID AND ANDREW HUMISTON. THE Subscribers having been appointed 1 by the Hon. Court of Probate for the District of Litchfeld, Commissioners on the Estates of

 DAVID HUMISTON and

 ANDREW HUMISTON,

 late of Harwinton, deceased, represented insolvent, hereby give notice, that six months from the 19th day of March, 1927, has been allowed the creditors of said estates to present their claims for al- lowance, and that they will attend to the bu- siness oftheir appointment at the house of the late deceased, on Monday the fourth day of June next, and on "Wednesday the 18th day of September next, at one o'clock on each of said days. All claims not then presented will be forever debarred recovery.

 JONATHAN ROSSETER,

 ABIJAH WEBSTER, CommrS. JOSIAH POND,

 Harwinton, March 19, 1927. 80

... ESTATES OF

 DAVID AND ANDREW HUMISTON.
For the further satisfaction of the public, the following Certificates are offered for peru sal

NORWICH, Vt, March IA. Shocking afdir.-We learn that Mir. Da- vid Jillson, of this town, was killed in Windham on Saturday last, by a man by he name of M'Nelly, ,an Irishman by birth. It appears from verbal statements given that the former. had employed the latter, who was a taylor, to make some clothes for him, and went to the shop at the time ap- pointed to get them-when a dispute a. rose about something, in which M'Nelly became furiously mad, plunged upon his disputant with pair of large shears in his hand, gave him two or three violent stabs, and otherwise assaulted him until every appearance of life was extinct. The hor- rid deed was soon found out by his neigh bours, and the perpetrator was immedi- ately secured. Medical aid was called in, and after much exertion MT. JiIlson was revived. He fingered through one or two days in extreme agony and finally expi- red.

 Female Presence 0f Mind.

 Count Segur in his recently published sMemoirs and recollections," relates the following anecdote of the princess Lubom- irska :--s'She was once in her sledge riding under the immense, canopy ofa sombre for est, when at the turn of narrow path, she came unexpectedly within a few steps of a bear rendered furious by hunger. At the approach of the wild animal, the horse made leap, and overturned the sledge. The bear advanced at the princess, an attendant rushed forward to save her, and placed himself between her and the terrible animal; he attacked it, but his sabre broke. An un- equal contest took place, but the bear soon caught the Pole in his paws. Without be- coming terrified, the princess took hold of two pistols that had fallen out of the sledge came behind the terrible animal, discharged two shots into his ear and stretched him dead at her feet"
Nnnw,nn. Nj. March 14.

Intended as Reading Book for Schools.

 By SAMUEL WILLIAMS, IL. D. The jollo,sing are some cf the Recommendations 9f this scork ;--

 "The History of the American Revolution written by the late Samuel Williams, IL. D. can cheerfully recommend as a suitable read ing book for schools. The facts are iudiciOus- ly selected, chronologically arranged, and ex- hibited in neat and vigorous style. JOSHUA BATES

 Pres. of Afiddle6ury College. "Our youth ought, at as early period as possible, to be made acquainted with the suf- ferings and services of the immortal sages and heroes that achieved the American Revolu- tion: and Doct. Williams work is we'll calcu. lated to answer this important purpose.

 DE WITT CLINTON" Numerous other testimonials of Gthe value of this little work might be added, hut the ahovr will suffice. Price S7 I-e cents.

 Extract of aletter from Capt. James H. Dill, late master of brig Potomac, of Bos- ton,

 "ST. CRUZ. Teneriffe, Nov. 20, 1926.

 "Sir: am sorry to have to announce to you the unfortunate loss of the Potomac. When we had performed .our quarantine, and discharged our cargo that we had to Grand Canary, we came directly to this place, and were waiting hero to obtain li- cence from the government to take passen- gers, for within few months an order has

 been sent out here, from the King, preven- ting aN foreign vessels from taking natives of these Islands away consequently we kept the vessel here to wait the result of an interview with the government, to go on with the expedition, and finally, few days previous to the loss of the vessel, we succeeded, and had taken in large quan- tity of store, &c. for the passengers and, the day before we were ready to sail for Lanzarretto, there came on one of the most tremendous hurricanes that the old est inhabitants remember to have witness ed in these islands. Notwithstanding it came on very suddenly, and right on shore, I had got off cabin cable.and anchor, from the shore, before the communication to the vessel became impracticable--b the storm ragged with incseasing fury, every vessel parted, and went on to the beach, one af- ter another, the wind hauled every fifteen | minutes, so that no vessel could ride strain on more than one cable, till at length my small bower parted, and the chain was let go, and scope vered out-the sea was very bad, the boats all washed away, the vessel was unable to bear so hard labour, and leaked very badly still every thing was done to keep her free, and save her, but all in vain-at half past 9, the best bower parted, and the chain and anchor would not bring her up, and she was dash ed against the rocks, and in five minutes nothing was to be seen of the Potomac but some small pieces afoat in the surf; and with her, my mate and cook shared the same fate the rest, some made their es- cape by throwing themselves from the yards and rigging on to the rocks, and some were thrown up by the sea on to the rocks, with broken arms and legs and have scarcely recovered yet sufficiently to write you description of the shocking scene. The general destruction, in all the island. has not left vessel that we can procure.''

 The Potomac was to take her passen- gers at Lanzaretto, and proceed to Monte Video.

full articles.headline: FOR SALE, A Bt, ASST FURNACE
full articles.article:
Situated in VERGENNES, in the State of Vermont, upon the falls of Otter Creek. The local situation of this Furnace is as good, if not better, than any in the State of Vermont, being in the village of Vergennes, and with in one hundred rods of water carriage to any part of the Lake, or New-York, by way of the Northern Canal. The best of OAR for making Stove Plates or Hollow Ware, may be had within few miles, or may be brought from the shores of Lake Champlan, by wa ter. Coal in great abundance may be had on ashort notice. The Furnace will be sold ve- ry low. Only part of the purchase money will be wanted this spring, the remainder in yearly payments: For further particulars inquire of MOSES COUPON,

 40 of Fair-Haven, Rutland Go. Vt.

full articles.headline: Spanish Ladies.
full articles.article: The dress of the Spanish lady is remarka- ply elegant, generally adorns very perfect shape. Black is the universal color, and the robe is most tastefully worked and vandyk- ed. A montilla or veil of black silk or lace and sometimes white lace, is thrown over the head, and leaving the face uncovered, falls gracefully over the head and shoulders and is confined at the waist by the arms of the wearer They are both expensive and particular in dressing their feet with neat ness, and their little shoes fit closely. The large black eye, the dark expressive glance, the soft blood-tinged olive of the glowing complexion, make tho unwilling English man confess the majesty of Spanish beauty and he feels that tho the soft blue eye, and delicate loveliness of his own countrywo- men awake amore tender feeling of interest he would deny or dispute, in vain, the com manding superiority of those dark-eyed and fair-formed damsels.

Continued. ~

 We had experienced for several days m sue cession nearly a dead calm. Campbell had heretofore admired and enjoyed this state of the elements, for what is better calculated to raise the contemplative mind from earthly matters than to behold in an autumn evening a cloudless sky reflected on the glassy surface of the slumbering ocean? But now the dead calm was torture to his restless spirit. He prayed for motion, and his impatlence was betrayed in every action. His eyes were wild and wandering, and his movements abrupt and hurried. He inquired of the oldest sea man from which quarter of the compass might. be expected the approach of the next tenn pest. and to that quarter were his eyes con stantly directed, where every ascending cloud appeared to bring a fresh hope to his desOlate heart.

 At length tie long looked for storm arose in all its grandeur. Volumes of dense clouds regularly and gradually ascended like forlni- dabIe armies preparing for battle. The winds that had been pent up, now burst forth, and the roaring waters heaved with a convulsive motion. The spell was broke that had har- monized creation, and discord now prevailed The appearance of Campbell became visibiy changed. His countenance was animated ;- there was a smile of terrible, but undefned meaning upon his lips; his eyes glanced wild ly from the sea te the heavens, and he tra- versed the deck with a rapidity of step that excited the wonder of all who beheld him. Our vessel was soon prepared to encounter the worst but as the wind blew steadily from one quarter we felt no apprehensions for eur safety.-The sky was completely overcast, and the rain descended in torrents. Campbell still remained upon deck, after all the passen- gers and crew, excepting those upon watch, had retired to rest. No persuasion could in- duce him to go below, and to the entreaties ofhis wife and the captain, he replied: " It is the only joyful hour l have experienced since came on board; Ibeseechs you not to interruptit."

 They left him, and he seated himselfin the most retired part of the ship, to brood upon his feelings had retired to my birth, but found it impossible to close my eyes, for the raging waters made such an awful coil as they dashed against the sides of the ship, and gave rise to reflections that would have kept me awake even had my mind been fortified with the philosophy of the little Captain. After tossing in my bed for about two hours, until the fever of my mind was communicated to my body, imagined hearda piercing shriek proceeding from the deck. It was immediate ly followed by groan. leaped from my bed and rushed to the gangway. l met the captain at the foot of the stairs, who had been awakened by the same noise. On seeing me, he exclaimed Mon dieu le melancaolique gentlehomme !" and ascended as rapidly as his ,diminutive legs would carry him. I follow ed him, and we hurried towards the place where we had left Campbell the preceding evening. m

 Lights were speedily brought, and lying on the deck we beheld Campbell, welterng in his blood. l raised him-the wound was in his bosom, and bleeding proftlsely.- "Good God '' exclaimed, "who has done 1his 2"

 "The Tempest Fiend," he answered. "We have had a long and fearful struggle ;- but thank God, it is over. Iproved unequal to the combat, and he has marked me for the caverns ofthe deep." He laughed hysterical- ly, and big drops of precipitation burst from his pale forehead. l called for assistance to carry him below.

 "NO, no," he cried, "let me die here. I shall be called fer before to-morrows sun ri- ses, for the spirits ofthe water are preparing my abode in their coral caves. Let me rest here until they come for me-"

 The captain demanded of the sailors who were on watch, an explanation of this melan- choly and mysterious occurrence. They sta kCN uAotS uulHIS IIC IntcTSdlS OI tue storm, they had heard voices, but conceived them to be nothing more than the rawlings of c Campbell One man, however, protested that immedi- ately after the shriek, vivid flash of lightning afforded him amomentary and indistinct view of figure gliding down the gangway of the forecastle. Suspicion Immediately fell on the shipwrecked stranger, for adyersty is too frequently considered by the prosperous, su- periOr to no action, however atrocious. The physician vouched for the innocence of his patient, declaring it physically impossible that he could stir from his hammock. He pro- nounced him in fair way to recover, but as yet incapable of moving. "And then what motiye," said he, could possibly exist in the bosom of man, himself apparently on the verge of eternity. sufficient to excite exhaust ed nature to the performance of the act of fend 2"

 Campbell was carried below, and after his wound was staunched, was left alone with his wife, the presence of any other person being painful to him. We then entered the place where the sick sailor lay, and on beholding him readily admitted that we did him injustice by ' the suspicion we had entertained. But as we were about to leave him, l imagined esped a speck of blood on the covering of the he'd. One of his hands hung over the side of the hammock; the light fell upon it. and betray- ed that 1t also was stained with blood Con victiOn flashed on the minds of all ,,ros.x4

full articles.headline: AZLegOric0L.
full articles.article: A traveller setting out upon long journey was assailed by CUTS, mastifs, ,and lfgrowu puppies, which came out of their kennels to bark at him as he passed along. He often dismounted from the horse to drive them back with stones and sticks, into their hiding places. This operation was repeated every day, and some times as often as twenty times day. The consequence was, that the travellers time was consumed in chastis- ing these dogs and puppies. At last he was overtaken by neighbor, who was going the some road ,but had set out long time after him. The latter traveller was very much surprized to find the other no further on his journey, and on hearing the reason, 'Alas" ssid he, lis it possible that you have; lost your time, and wasted your strength in this useless way? These same ani- malls have beset me all along the road, ,bu, I have saved my time and my labor, in taking no notice of their barkings; while you have lost yours in resenting insults VI 'ch did you no harm, and in chastising dogs & puppies whose manners you can never mend. .''-V;2ps. .>

ESTATES OF DAVID AND ANDREW HUMISTON. THE Subscribers having been appointed 1 by the Hon. Court of Probate for the District of Litchfeld, Commissioners on the Estates of

 DAVID HUMISTON and

 ANDREW HUMISTON,

 late of Harwinton, deceased, represented insolvent, hereby give notice, that six months from the 19th day of March, 1927, has been allowed the creditors of said estates to present their claims for al- lowance, and that they will attend to the bu- siness oftheir appointment at the house of the late deceased, on Monday the fourth day of June next, and on "Wednesday the 18th day of September next, at one o'clock on each of said days. All claims not then presented will be forever debarred recovery.

 JONATHAN ROSSETER,

 ABIJAH WEBSTER, CommrS. JOSIAH POND,

 Harwinton, March 19, 1927. 80

full articles.headline: Nnnw,nn. Nj. March 14.
full articles.article:
NORWICH, Vt, March IA. Shocking afdir.-We learn that Mir. Da- vid Jillson, of this town, was killed in Windham on Saturday last, by a man by he name of M'Nelly, ,an Irishman by birth. It appears from verbal statements given that the former. had employed the latter, who was a taylor, to make some clothes for him, and went to the shop at the time ap- pointed to get them-when a dispute a. rose about something, in which M'Nelly became furiously mad, plunged upon his disputant with pair of large shears in his hand, gave him two or three violent stabs, and otherwise assaulted him until every appearance of life was extinct. The hor- rid deed was soon found out by his neigh bours, and the perpetrator was immedi- ately secured. Medical aid was called in, and after much exertion MT. JiIlson was revived. He fingered through one or two days in extreme agony and finally expi- red.

 Female Presence 0f Mind.

 Count Segur in his recently published sMemoirs and recollections," relates the following anecdote of the princess Lubom- irska :--s'She was once in her sledge riding under the immense, canopy ofa sombre for est, when at the turn of narrow path, she came unexpectedly within a few steps of a bear rendered furious by hunger. At the approach of the wild animal, the horse made leap, and overturned the sledge. The bear advanced at the princess, an attendant rushed forward to save her, and placed himself between her and the terrible animal; he attacked it, but his sabre broke. An un- equal contest took place, but the bear soon caught the Pole in his paws. Without be- coming terrified, the princess took hold of two pistols that had fallen out of the sledge came behind the terrible animal, discharged two shots into his ear and stretched him dead at her feet"

 Pres. of Afiddle6ury College. "Our youth ought, at as early period as possible, to be made acquainted with the suf- ferings and services of the immortal sages and heroes that achieved the American Revolu- tion: and Doct. Williams work is we'll calcu. lated to answer this important purpose.

 DE WITT CLINTON" Numerous other testimonials of Gthe value of this little work might be added, hut the ahovr will suffice. Price S7 I-e cents.
